avalancheActivity.comment: Avalanche danger is moderate in general. On steep slopes in all aspects, naturally triggered glide-snow/wet-snow avalanches caan be expected. Open glide cracks are indicators of imminent danger. In addition, at high altitudes in extended east-facing terrain behind discontinuities there are snowdrift accumulations which in places can be triggered by 1 person, releases reaching medium-to-large size.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Naturally triggered glide-snow avalanches in steep terrain

snowpackStructure.comment: At high altitudes, ridgeline snowdrift accumulations have been generated by minor fresh snow and moderate W/NW winds, on Tuesday stormy winds can transport the snow further, the drifts have not yet bonded with the snowpack surface. At intermediate and lower altitudes the snowpack is very moist-to-wet due to rain impact, can glide over smooth ground.

tendency.comment: Due to slowly rising temperatures, the snowdrift problem will recede. The gliding snow problem will persist.

weatherForecast.comment:
Due to a NW airstream, moist/cool air masses will move into the northern flank of the Alps on Tuesday, heavy clouds will accompany them, the summits will be veiled in fog. Above 1000 m repeated bouts of light snowfall, mostly between Dachstein and Totes Gebirge. By afternoon the clouds will recede. The NW winds will be strong, stormy on east-facing slopes. On the southern flank of the Alps conditions will be far more pleasant, with foehn-induced sunshine in the morning. At 2000 m: -6 degrees; at 1500 m: -2 degrees.
Following a brief nocturnal interim high, a warm front will arrive on Ash Wednesday, bringing variably conditions and instable weather. Winds will be lighter, temperatures slightly higher, hardly any precipitation is expected.

avalancheActivity.comment: Avalanche danger is generally low. At high altitudes in extended east facing terrain, small snowdrift accumulations which in places can be triggered by 1 person, releases reaching medium-to-large size. On steep slopes in all aspects, naturally triggered glide-snow and wet-snow avalanches can be expected.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Some fresh snowdrifts at high altitudes, isolated glide-snow/wet-snow avalanches in steep terrain

avalancheProblems.comment: small, thin snowdrifts at high altitudes

snowpackStructure.comment: At high altitudes, ridgeline snowdrift accumulations have been generated by minor fresh snow and moderate W/NW winds, often poorly bonded with the snowpack surface. At intermediate and lower altitudes the snowpack is very moist-to-wet due to rain impact, can glide over smooth ground. The slopes are becoming bare of snow.

weatherForecast.comment:
Due to a NW airstream, moist/cool air masses will move into the northern flank of the Alps on Tuesday, heavy clouds will accompany them, the summits will be veiled in fog. Above 1000 m repeated bouts of light snowfall, mostly between Dachstein and Totes Gebirge. By afternoon the clouds will recede. The NW winds will be strong, stormy on east-facing slopes. On the southern flank of the Alps conditions will be far more pleasant, with foehn-induced sunshine in the morning. At 2000 m: -6 degrees; at 1500 m: -2 degrees.
Following a brief nocturnal interim high, a warm front will arrive on Ash Wednesday, bringing variably conditions and instable weather. Winds will be lighter, temperatures slightly higher, hardly any precipitation is expected.
